unnormalised: A recent leak online has put many on edge. It seems a database containing educational and employment identifiers has been compromised. Initial reports suggest that the breach includes records related to several Indian institutions, including IIT Delhi and a few IIMs. Some are even saying that details from UPSC exam candidates may be involved!
normalised: A recent leak online has put many on edge. It seems a database containing educational and employment identifiers has been compromised. Initial reports suggest that the breach includes records related to several Indian institutions, including I-I-T Delhi and a few I-I-M-s. Some are even saying that details from U-P-S-C exam candidates may be involved!

unnormalised: The leaked data allegedly includes things like roll numbers from the 2022-2023 academic year (example: 22/IITD/MSC/007), employee IDs starting with prefixes like "EMP" (e.g., EMP12345 SBI), and unique application numbers used for job postings (like APPL2023_0001). People are particularly concerned about the potential for misuse of this info.
normalised: The leaked data allegedly includes things like roll numbers from the two thousand twenty two to two thousand twenty three academic year (example: two two slash I-I-T-D slash M-S-C slash zero zero seven), employee I-D-s starting with prefixes like "E-M-P" (e.g., E-M-P one two three four five S-B-I), and unique application numbers used for job postings (like A-P-P-L two thousand twenty three underscore zero zero zero one). People are particularly concerned about the potential for misuse of this info.

unnormalised: Security expert, Mr. Sharma, warned against phishing attempts. He suggested changing passwords and being extra vigilant when receiving emails or calls asking for personal info. He said, "Criminals might use leaked data to impersonate university officials or employers." He added that everyone should enable 2FA where possible.
normalised: Security expert, Mister Sharma, warned against phishing attempts. He suggested changing passwords and being extra vigilant when receiving emails or calls asking for personal info. He said, "Criminals might use leaked data to impersonate university officials or employers." He added that everyone should enable two-F-A where possible.

unnormalised: The govt. cyber cell is investigating, and they've asked affected institutions to cooperate. It’s unclear exactly how many people are affected, but early estimations point to a number upwards of 50,000. Several people have reported recieving fraudulent emails already. One user said they had recieved an email regarding a "failed KYC check" and were asked to input their Aadhar number.
normalised: The government cyber cell is investigating, and they've asked affected institutions to cooperate. It’s unclear exactly how many people are affected, but early estimations point to a number upwards of fifty thousand. Several people have reported receiving fraudulent emails already. One user said they had received an email regarding a "failed K-Y-C check" and were asked to input their Aadhar number.

unnormalised: Authorities advise checking your bank statements for any suspicious activity and reporting anything out of the ordinary to your local police station. Remember folks, stay safe online! Always be cautious of links and attachments in suspicious emails. Better safe than sorry, right?
normalised: Authorities advise checking your bank statements for any suspicious activity and reporting anything out of the ordinary to your local police station. Remember folks, stay safe online! Always be cautious of links and attachments in suspicious emails. Better safe than sorry, right?
